I was a bio major in CAS, and my best friend was a bio major in CALS.

Similarities:

* General coursework for the major are identical between both colleges. This also goes for the concentrations you can take.
* Resources and opportunities were the same, as biological sciences is a "special" major than spans 3 different colleges, so everything is centralized

Differences:

* Tuition. CAS offers grants, since its an endowed college. CALS, as far as I know, does not. So depending on where you fall in the financial aid area, you could pay less to attend CALS, if you're a New_York State resident, versus going to CAS. On the other hand, if you're in a situation like me, even if you are a New_York State resident, you could end up paying less to go to CAS rather than CALS. Unfortunately, financial aid is rather opaque about this, but I would recommend applying to CALS if you're in-state. Otherwise, go for CAS.

* Graduation requirements differ between the colleges. As a CAS student, I **had** to take 5 distribution courses (had to fulfill 4 out of the 5 "categories" [you could double up on one]: historical analysis, cultural analysis, literature and the arts, knowledge, cognition, and moral reasoning, and social and behavioral analysis), a course that covers pre-1900 history outside of the Western world (can be two classes, one on pre-1900 history and one outside of the Western world), and a language requirement (11 credits in a single language or pass a 2000-level course). As a result, my schedule was fuller than his, particular towards junior and senior year. However, because of the wide variety of classes to choose from, it didn't really impact my academic experience, and I thoroughly enjoyed my distribution requirements. I ended up getting a minor in history because I discovered that I loved the subject, and I very nearly got a minor in psychology as well (1 credit short). CALS has different requirements than CAS. They don't require you to take a foreign language, for example.

* You get a BA from CAS and a BS from CALS, but that doesn't really matter if you're going to grad school or applying to jobs.

* Your alumni resources, and other on-campus resources, vary. CAS has a larger alumni network since its the largest college. This doesn't really matter too much, since you're a Cornell alumnus/ae first, rather than a CALS/CAS alumnus/ae. Your advising offices are also different, and have different resources, though they pull from a nearly identical pool.
